Award.AwardTitle: Connecting Women in Mathematics: AWM Research Symposium 2013 and Workshop 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM) is developing a series of interconnected research conferences and workshops designed to create ongoing networks, encourage research collaborations, and build a stronger sense of community among women in the mathematical sciences. This project includes the first two events in this series, AWM Research Symposium 2013 and AWM Workshop at JMM 2014. The symposium, to be held March 16-17, 2013 at Santa Clara University, will include three distinguished plenary speakers, special sessions on a broad array of topics in pure and applied mathematics, contributed paper sessions, poster presentations, and a panel discussion. All presenters will be women, but the event will be open to the entire mathematical community and will be advertised widely. Mathematics of Planet Earth 2013, an initiative launched by the mathematical sciences institutes of North America to showcase the relevance of the mathematical sciences in solving the challenges facing our planet, will be featured in one of the invited addresses and in several of the special sessions. The AWM Workshop at the Joint Mathematics Meetings in Baltimore in January 2014, will be aimed at women early in their careers. It will concentrate on diverse aspects of the mathematics of shape modeling and will feature a daylong special session on this subject, a general topic poster session, and a reception with a mentoring component. The need for mathematical shape modeling and image analysis arises in fields such as computer vision, computer animation, and biomedical engineering. Questions from shape analysis often lead to rich mathematical problems in areas like statistics, variational methods, optimization, and geometry.

While the problem of under representation of women in the mathematical sciences is persistent and complex and has no single solution, events that bring together women at various stages of their careers for networking, mentoring and research collaboration create a synergy that goes beyond that of a standard research conference. Such events can have a significant impact on the aspirations and future career trajectories of young women. AWM's planned series of conferences and workshops is designed to build community and to promote networking, natural mentoring relationships, and research collaborations among women in mathematics, especially among those just beginning their careers. This project will help fund the first two of these events, a broad-based research symposium and a focused workshop for early-career women.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project involved two major events organized by the Association for Women in Mathematics (AWM).  The first was the AWM Research Symposium 2013, held at Santa Clara University in March 2013.  The Symposium included 3 plenary talks by distinguished women mathematicians, 10 special sessions on a wide range of topics in the mathematical sciences, and a panel discussion on the “imposter syndrome,” a challenge faced by many women pursuing STEM careers.  The Symposium attracted 159 registered participants, including both women and men.

 

The second event was a Workshop on the Mathematics of Shape Modeling held at the Joint Mathematics Meetings (JMM) in Baltimore, in January 2014.  The workshop featured 12 talks by early-career women and a poster session for graduate students.  Also held in conjunction with the workshop, there was a mentoring luncheon and a panel discussion on career development.  While the presenters at these events were all women, selected on the basis of their research contributions, the workshop was open to all registered participants of the JMM, the largest annual mathematics meeting in the world. 

 

Intellectual Merit:  The Symposium and Workshop both featured talks on significant new research in areas of current interest in the mathematical sciences.  Plenary talks at the Symposium included a talk on the Mathematics of Planet Earth, part of a year long initiative to showcase the relevance of the mathematical sciences in solving the challenges facing our planet.  Also featured was a talk by Maryam Mirzakhani, the first woman to receive a Fields Medal, on her seminal work in symplectic topology.

 

The Workshop focused the mathematics of shape modeling and image analysis, a field with broad applications to computer animation, computer vision, and biomedical engineering.  Talks addressed mathematical problems in statistics, optimization, variational methods, and geometry arising from these applications.

 

Broader Impact:  These events were designed to address the persistent lack of adequate representation of women in the mathematical sciences through mentoring, career advice, and network building.

 

Networks based on shared research interests are particularly effective in stimulating collaborations, increasing participation at conferences, and spawning natural mentoring relationships.  The Symposium special sessions and the JMM Workshop were based on shared research interests.  The Workshop drew, in part, on participants of a prior conference for women in shape modeling, reinforce a growing network in that area. In addition to network building, panel discussions at both events and mentor pairings at the Workshop provided valuable career advice.

 

Finally, it is well documented that the subconscious association of “mathematician” with “male” leads to implicit bias against women in the field.  The Symposium and Workshop supported by this project were open to the broader mathematical community and attendees included both men and women.  Featuring a large number of presentations by women highlighting their research contributions, events such as these help to weaken the associations leading to implicit bias.
